children.subject: Moving forward, I am specifically interested in how we can prevent situation like these to happen again? It's ok to enroll fewer ppl if we don't have the resource. It is unfortunate, but its no ones fault. Maybe we can be informed earlier, since students plan their enrollment strategy according to the classes? I find it hard to believe 189 can just suddenly decide no webcast 2 weeks before the semester begin. Can important factors like these be set in stone earlier on?

This is a great point and one that I think every one here, student and faculty, needs to seriously consider. Huge class sizes especially force instructors to limit the scope of the class and force students to learn the material on their own. Combined with the difficulty of actually receiving help (I once went to project office hours, sat there for six hours, and wasn’t able to get my question answered by any of the TAs, and other students didn’t know the answer either), it does make a person question what value they’re actually receiving. 

Another point I would offer is that our resources are so focused on accommodating new students that our class offerings have become more limited/have no room to expand. We only have a single class on most topics—sure, there’s grad classes, but those are few and far between. If you want to further explore a topic, you have very few options. You can take some related classes, but there’s no advanced version to further your studies. 

We may also want to consider how we as students can alleviate and compensate for the pressure on the universities resources. Students can struggle to find study groups and tutoring—surely other students can organize informal study parties and homework meet ups. It’s not a perfect solution, but it’s one that can help. 

I agree with you that this is a problem we as a campus community needs to come together and solve, and I am glad that someone is speaking out about this.

history.content:
As many of you have noticed, we are experiencing unprecedented number of cs intended students. However, it seems really hard for EECS department to meet such increasing demand. I received email about EECS127 cutting discussion sessions earlier in summer and now over enrollment in CS189. It is really stressful to see people asking chance of getting off wait list or to imagine a 100+ student discussion next semester. On the other hand, expanding classes seems good for everyone but will lower class quality and inevitably decrease support for each student in the long term. If we have enough resources and limited class sizes like private schools, many of the following problems are not problems. However, given our capacity, they are some very realistic concerns.

I am posting here to express some concern about Berkeley CS & EECS. I think they should be not only the concern of the department but also the concern for everyone here. It would also be good for the department and professors to provide some meetings or polling to let the students express their concerns and offer suggestions. If you want to express your concerns, please comment in the post and i will try to list them here. If you want to suggest what can we/EECS department do, I think we can also post them here.

1. How can we ensure the quality and support in upper divs given our limited resources while lower divs are aiming to accept more students into the major. If upper div classes are expanded, they need more TAs. Several days ago I noticed that CS61A piazza said it is looking for lab assistance but the lowest GPA requirement is only C-. We not only need more TAs and assistants but incoming students would also need staff from whom they can get clear and accurate answer.

2. L&S is intended to help "undecided" students explore what they could do but is now misinterpreted as a shortcut to get admitted to CS. And a lot of students are affected by others to choose CS while not considering other potential pathways. How can we deal with this. How can we tell people that CS is not the only way to success.

3. I noticed some students who really loved CS are discouraged by the class size. To be specific, if such a student want to ask a CS question that is a bit of out of the scope of the class, when he/she go to office hours and see a long queue and also understand that other students need more help, what will he do? Although these students might find other resources like labs to help them, the opportunity cost become higher. I would also say most of the students do CS because they want to get a CS job. However, its been much harder to find a geek, a maker, a lover, a scholar in class (I know we have clubs but i am talking about atmosphere of student body which should reflected not only in clubs). The atmosphere need to change.

4. There are more groups awaiting help than our resources. For example, ethnic & gender diversity in EECS. For example, students who have no prior experiences of CS. How should limited resources[not only class size but also quality] be distributed?
history.subject: Concern about CS Upper Divs
